test1.title: Why we need to play
test1.instructions: For questions 1-8, read the text below and decide which answer (A, B, C or D) best fits each gap. Mark your answers on the separate answer sheet.
test1.passage:
Human beings are not the only creatures that like to {1} fun. Many animals play, as do some birds. However, no other creatures spend so much time enjoying themselves as human beings do. Indeed, we {2} our sense of fun right into adulthood.

So why do human beings spend so much time playing? One reason is that we have time for leisure; animals have very little time to play as most of their life is spent sleeping and {3} food.

So is play just an opportunity for us to {4} in enjoyable activities or does it have a more important {5}? According to scientists, {6} from being fun, play has several very real {7} for us â€“ it helps our physical, intellectual and social development. It also helps us {8} for what we have not yet experienced. With very little risk, we can act out what we would do in unexpected, or even dangerous, situations.

gaps.explanation: The correct phrase is 'have fun', but among the options, 'hold' is the closest to maintaining or experiencing enjoyment.
'Seeking' means actively pursuing or maintaining something. We 'seek' our sense of fun means we actively pursue and maintain our enjoyment.
'Engage' means to participate actively in something. Animals spend time 'engaging' in the activity of finding food.
'Purpose' refers to the reason or aim for which something exists. The question asks if play has a more important 'purpose' beyond enjoyment.
'Apart from' is a prepositional phrase meaning 'in addition to' or 'besides'. 'Apart from being fun' means 'in addition to being enjoyable'.
'Benefits' means positive effects or advantages. Play has several real 'benefits' for human development.
'Prepare' means to make ready for something. Play helps us 'prepare' for future experiences we haven't encountered yet.
'Little' means small in amount. 'With very little risk' means with minimal danger or chance of harm.
